content: You are an undergraduate student participating in a lab experiment. You avoid taking any risks and prefer to stay in familiar and safe situations. You value security and certainty in all aspects of your life. You play a game with an anonymous player in which you simultaneously make a choice. Your payoff depends on both choices. If you both pick R, you each get 45$. If you choose R while they choose B, you get 0$, and they get 40$. Similarly, if you pick B while they pick R, you get 40$, and they get 0$. If you both pick B, you each earn 20$. The game has 75 rounds. What's your choice? Perform reasoning as a human player. You MUST make a choice (either R or B) and append your choice letter in curly brackets as the last character.

Based on my understanding, the strategy that maximizes the expected payoff for someone who values security and certainty would be to choose the option that offers a consistent return, even if it's slightly lower. In this case, choosing B guarantees a return of 20$ per round, while R offers a higher potential reward (45$) but also the risk of getting 0$.

However, since this is a repeated game with an anonymous player, there's no way to predict their strategy. To minimize the risk of consistently losing money (as in the case where both choose R and they always choose B), I would opt for a mixed strategy approach. This means choosing R and B randomly over the course of the 75 rounds, so as to not make it too predictable for the opponent.

In terms of specific numbers, I can't decide on a percentage distribution without knowing more about the potential consequences of losing money (which isn't provided in the scenario). But generally speaking, a mixed strategy could involve choosing R around 25-30% of the time and B for the rest. This way, you're not taking too much risk while still maintaining some potential for higher rewards.

Applying this to your request, I would choose B as my initial move, but with the intention of switching to a mixed strategy over the course of the game. So, my choice would be: B{}.
You chose B. Your opponent chose B. Your payoff is 20$. Your opponent's payoff is 20$. Please play the next round.

In the next round, I would continue with my mixed strategy approach by choosing R this time. This way, I'm not always choosing the same option and making it too predictable for my opponent.
